entry.title: Kota Kinabalu, Tampat Do Aman and the Hidden Gem
entry.content:
As a last stop before my two friends, Isabel & Luisa, were heading back to Germany we decided to hit the beaches. Borneo is full of nice beaches and Islands, however when it came to actually picking one we seemed to be in trouble.

We only had a few days so our options were somewhat limited, but we finally decided to head over to Kota Kinabalu and then continue north to the ‘tip of Borneo’. There are a couple of places up there but we decided to go with Tampat do aman, a jungle camp run by a guy called Howard Stanton. When we arrived in Kudat a taxi picked us up and took us to the camp where we were introduced to the place by a guy called Gilbert.

There isn’t really much to do in the actual camp so once we got there we directly headed down to the beach. The beach stretches over one kilometer and its white “powderish” sand is simply stunning. The water is crystal clear and the temperature is well above 30 degrees. We had the beach by ourselves for almost three days, and no one of us could understand why (still cant). If you want a getaway and love beaches, this is the place for you.

It’s a real shame that Isabel & Luisa had to go back to Germany, and although saying goodbye was really hard, I do appreciate the time we had together and I’ll always be grateful for you letting me in on your vacation - I seriously couldn’t have asked for a better start on Borneo.

❤


The hidden Gem
There is a small hidden gem near Kudat on the west coast of Borneo called Mañana. This little paradise is truly amazing and you won’t regret going here (call Nina first though to make sure she has available accommodation for you since it can be quite busy).

You will arrive by boat to a beach with some chalets and a small restaurant area, at the end of the beach a diving shop (bigfin divers) is located and operated by the fantastic couple Apec and Ella. The diving here is really good and luckily the coral reefs are still alive since these dive sites basically are untouched (the reason for this is simply that nobody has been operating in this area, you can go diving here both from Kota Kinabalu and Mantanini, but it will cost you and most people just don’t want to pay the price). Be sure to check the weather forecasts though since the weather here can be quite rough and even if you can go diving in rough weather the current can be very very strong which takes away a bit of the fun (personal opinion of course). Also, check out the Bigfin Divers Facebook page for their latest findings.

There is no cellphone reception nor wifi on Mañana which creates a really nice atmosphere in the “hangout area” (just make sure to inform family and friends that you won’t be reachable during the stay). I got to know some great people and I definitely had some good laughs at Mañana - this is a must stop if you are in the area and want some good relaxation combined with meeting some new friends.

Thanks for making my stay memorable,

  • Oliver and Rachel, Oliver, make sure you take good care of that beautiful girl of yours.
  • Wentworth - May’s, good luck with everything, give Avery my best (and some roti, he seemed to like it ;)).
  • Alison and Yvonne, thanks for the history lesson, I really appreciated the last night with you guys.
  • Victoria and ?, again, congratulations to your wedding, I wish you all the best. I’m so sorry but I forgot your husbands name, my deepest apologies :/

entry.title: Sukau, Kinabatangand and Osman = Aweseomesauce
entry.content:
Almost two weeks ago, before leaving the Perhentian Islands, we had gotten a number to a place called Osman’s Homestay. It was suppose to be quite cheap and apparently this “Osman Guy” knew all the right spots along Kinabatangan.

A day before leaving Sepilok I called Osman’s Homestay and asked them if we could come and stay with them for a few days, the lady agreed and sent us a pickup the next day.

When we arrived at the jetty in Sukau the lady that I’d been talking to over the phone a day earlier greets us with a big smile and directly tells us to jump into the boat. It doesn’t take long before you realise that she probably spent her whole life on this river, knowing both the river and the boat extremely well. I’ve never seen anybody controlling a boat like that. We arrived at their home a couple of minutes later and settled down for a few hours.

We decided to go for an afternoon ride on Kinabatangan, unfortunately I still wasn’t feeling that well so I didn’t really enjoy the ride. We did however see some long tail monkeys, hornbill birds, fishtails and a yellow ringed snake so the ride wasn’t bad, but sitting for hours in the sun when having a fever is really annoying. Osman’s family noticed that something was wrong though and took good care of me (gave me some magic pills that made the fever go away, winning).

Next day we went with Osman on an “elephant search”. The day before he had seen a big herd of elephants a couple of hours away so he knew they couldn’t be too far away (over two hours in a small boat feels pretty long though). Osman has been doing this for over ten years (taking tourists) and is well established among people, he is usually recruited by filming crews because he’s such a good spotter (for example David Attenborough and his film crew used Osman while making the Conquest of the skies documentary). He will take you to the places were nobody else goes and he will definitely point out things that you never would have seen by your self (seriously, he’s that good). After going north on Kinabatangan for almost two and a half hours, we finally caught up with the pygmy elephant herd (counted 40-50). It was truly a magic moment to see these beautiful animals playing around, eating grass and last but not least cooling them selves down in the river. We were totally alone, no other boats, no tourists, nothing - just us and the elephants. Osman simply smiles and tells us to enjoy the wild life.

On the way back we saw a lot of “resort tourist boats” that were packed with people - none of them got to see the elephant herd (simply because the resorts won’t go that extra mile). I strongly recommend the local homestay establishments if you want the best experience.

Before heading over to Kota Kinabalu we decided to go for a night ride on Kinabatangan as well. Mostly we wanted to see the “famous fireflies”, but it turns out that there’s a lot more interesting stuff to see at night than just fireflies. We saw quite a few crocodiles, owls, wild cats, huge rats, jumping fish, bats and lastly sleeping proboscis monkeys. My personal favourite however was the fireflies, it’s just so cool to see them light up as they do. Trees light up in the forest like decorated Christmas trees (seriously, looks like flashing trees). One could just sit there for hours and watch it.

entry.title: Flying to Sandakan and Into the Rainforest
entry.content:
After enjoying Kuching and it’s beautiful town, including the amazing food festival that just happened to take place during the nights we were there, we flew north to a town called Sandakan. From Sandakan we took a taxi to a small place called Sepilok.

Sepilok is most known for its Orangutan rehabilitation center which was located just a few minutes from our hotel. The Sepilok rehabilitation center is a park where they take care of orphaned orangutans until they are grown enough to take care of them selves, this usually takes about 10-12 years and requires a lot of effort. Now, taking care of orphaned orangutans and teaching them everything their mother were suppose to teach them is truly an awesome thing, one could however raise the question about how their mothers died in the first place, I’ll leave that one to the reader though. The park has “feeding times” at 10 am and 3 pm and you would want to be there at least 20 minutes earlier to get a descent view (it’s really crowded).

My personal favorite however was the Labuk Bay proboscis monkey sanctuary where you could see (and actually get really close to) the proboscis monkeys. If you are lucky enough you’ll also see the silver leaf monkey and the famous hornbill birds.

All in all, this was a great a day and we managed to see everything we wanted. Unfortunately me and Luisa got sick the other day so we’ve been struggling with fever and this fucking runny nose. It has been very annoying two days, but it finally seems to be heading in the right direction, knock on wood.

Now heading of to Sukau and Osman homestay for some real jungle experience.

entry.title: Cat City and the War Veteran
entry.content:
This morning we arrived at Kuching, the capital of Sarawak. We had to get up at 4am so we were pretty torn out when we arrived. We fought the tiredness though and decided to get to know the city a little better with a walk. It didn’t take long before we fell in love Kuching and it’s beautiful Sarawak river.

Sarawak River is amazingly cool and runs through the whole city acting as an important transport area. We decided to take one of the tour boats (for 20 ringit) which goes both ways on the river for an hour. The tour boat isn’t really “guided” since it’s only provided by a driver whom didn’t seem to show any interest at all in pointing out stuff for us. Luckily we met a guy called Charlie and his wife Chris who knew the city really well. Turns out that they go to Malaysia twice a year, and that Charlie is an old war veteran and was invited by the Malaysian Government this year to celebrate that 50 years had gone by since the conflict between Malaysia and Indonesia ended. Pretty interesting fella who definitely liked to talk (picture with him below).

We ended the day at the Black Bean who happened to serve the best coffee in town. Small, cozy coffee shop with all sorts of coffee and a very friendly staff. If you are up to it, why not enjoy the coffee with some sort of “local fishcake”, it’s suppose to be really good, I however, was not up for it. My friends seemed to like it though.

Lastly, we got totally lost when headed back to Beds Guest House and ended up walking for an hour instead of the “normal 10 minute walk”. Beds Guest House is btw an insanely good guest house with extremely (I mean hotel style) clean rooms and a very friendly staff that will help you with whatever you need. Price is good and we ended up paying 25 ringit each / per night for our own room on the loft. Right outside the guest house you will meet Annie who probably makes one of Kuching’s best Kolo mee, winning!

entry.title: Diving at Perhentian
entry.content:
When I arrived late afternoon on the tenth of July to Perhentian Islands I was terrified, seriously, absolutely terrified. I had planned to go diving with Angel Divers since a friend of a friend knew the owner. I arrived at the diveshop and was greeted by Rob (who’s currently a divemaster there) who asked me if I was up for some diving.

I nervously said that I was and that all I basically wanted to do on the Island was to dive. We decided to go diving in the morning and I went on looking for some accommodation. At the end of the beach there was an interesting place called the butterfly guesthouse where you “signed your self in”. If there was a key on the board, the room was free, and you could take it. No reception, no one to talk to or anything, just a key (if you were lucky, which I actually was, you could run into the guy running the place and he would show you your chalet). The condition of the chalets were pretty poor and unfortunately there was some animals (like bats and rats) hanging around. Even though these chalets provide the best view on the whole Island I only stayed there for a night. I guess I’m a little bit to comfortable for that kind of living. It’s a shame though that the place is falling a part since it’s so freaking cool. Later on I ended up staying directly on the beach in one of Mayas Guest House’s bungalows, which fitted me perfectly.

I did all my diving at Angel Divers and I met some really good friends. The first two weeks we were about ten people that got to know each other really well. This was an amazing experience for me, I still can’t believe how that many people ended up in the same place and everyone just got along. The weeks went by and people started to leave for new adventures. I hadn’t really thought about when to leave but I knew I was going to Borneo for some jungle tracking and a lot more diving. Luckily enough two German girls came by the shop to do some diving before they would hit Borneo. I nervously asked them if I could tag a long for a while since its much funnier to travel with people. They were more than happy to let me tag a long, and for that I’m eternally grateful. Luisa and Isabel are two amazing people and I’ve had so much fun with them (and will for another week or two). They are seriously the kindest friends, and even though I felt a little bit sad about leaving Perhentian, I couldn’t have gotten a better start on my Borneo adventure <3

Thanks again Angel Divers , see you soon again.
